persona.name: Malia Begay

occupation.title: Community Cultural Program Coordinator / Part-time Community Health Outreach Worker / Artisan (self-employed)
occupation.organization: Tse'yi' Community Center (tribal), and 'Begay Traditions' micro-business
occupation.description:
Malia splits her time between part-time paid work at the local community center and running a small home-based craft business. At the community center she coordinates cultural programs: organizes weekly Din�e9 language circle sessions, schedules elders to teach traditional weaving and songs, arranges youth mentorship activities, writes short grant applications for small local funding, and helps plan cultural events (for NA/Indigenous Heritage Days, seasonal ceremonies, and food-sharing gatherings). As a community health outreach worker (part of the center's health outreach grants) she performs basic screenings at events, distributes public-health flyers, assists with vaccination events, and checks on isolated elders via phone and home visits.

For her small business she produces and sells woven rugs (small rugs and table runners), beaded jewelry, and embroidered items. She markets these at regional markets, a small Etsy shop, and on Facebook Marketplace. She handles all aspects: design, production, photography, order fulfillment, bookkeeping, pricing, and occasional shipping. Her role requires bilingual communication (English and Din�e9), event coordination, basic accounting, community trust-building, simple grantwriting, and practical hands-on craft skills. Her key difficulties are limited time because of childcare, inconsistent cash flow, and navigating tribal and external grant paperwork. She is reliable in person, trusted by elders, and often acts as a mediator between younger families and tribal administrators.

persona.residence: Chinle / Canyon de Chelly area, Navajo Nation, Arizona, USA
persona.education: High school graduate (Chinle High School), attended Din�e9 College for two years with coursework in Native Studies and Early Childhood Education; completed a community certificate in Community Health Outreach and a short vocational certificate in small-business bookkeeping. Did not complete an associate's degree due to childcare and work obligations. Has taken numerous local workshops in traditional weaving, beadwork, and Navajo language revitalization.
long_term_goals: Help revitalize and pass on Din�e9 (Navajo) language and traditional crafts to the next generation through community programs and classes.
Build a small, sustainable micro-business selling high-quality traditional textiles and beadwork that can provide steady income and hire one assistant from the community.
Gain stable financial footing: move from paycheck-to-paycheck living to having an emergency fund covering 3 months of expenses within 5 years.
Create a community elder-youth exchange program that pairs fluent elders with teenagers for weekly storytelling, language practice, and skills transfer.
See her son graduate high school and go on to some form of higher education or trade that suits him; be able to support that without taking on crippling debt.
Secure a small grant for cultural programming at the tribal center that funds two annual events celebrating Din�e9 arts, food, and language.
Maintain health and avoid the chronic conditions that affect many in her family by establishing regular medical checkups, better sleep, and consistent physical activity.
persona.style: Warm, reserved, and deliberate. Malia speaks English with a noticeable Southwestern cadence and occasionally slips Din�e9 words and phrases into conversations when she wants to emphasize cultural concepts; she is fully bilingual in practical terms (daily speech, storytelling, and community work) though she sometimes searches for formal vocabulary. She uses a measured, storytelling tone when teaching or recounting history, with a soft laugh and steady eye contact when speaking to people she knows. With outsiders she is polite, somewhat formal at first, and slower to reveal personal details. She smiles easily and uses small physical gestures (touching a bead necklace, tucking hair behind an ear) when thinking. She is indirect when criticizing: prefers to suggest rather than confront; uses metaphors and traditional sayings to teach a lesson. She favors practical clothing: denim, long skirts layered with leggings, sturdy boots or moccasins, and always wears a turquoise or silver piece of jewelry that belonged to a relative. At community events she blends modern and traditional: graphic tee under a woven sash, hair braided, shawl or ribbon skirt for ceremonial occasions. She prefers phone calls for elders, text for peers, and Facebook events for broad community announcements. She often begins conversations with a brief acknowledgment of lineage and place (a Din�e9 custom) which can feel formal to newcomers but anchors her interactions.

traits: Deeply community-oriented: puts group needs and cultural continuity high on her priority list.
Patient teacher: can slow down explanations, repeat without frustration, and uses stories to make points memorable.
Resilient and practical: adapts to resource constraints and finds low-cost solutions.
Modestly ambitious: wants upward mobility but is cautious about risky debt or flashy promises.
Protective and maternal toward younger people in the community; organizes informal babysitting co-ops.
Cautious with strangers but generous with neighbors; hospitality is a core value.
Values tradition but pragmatic about modern conveniences: will use social media to sell rugs.
Can become quietly stubborn when defending cultural protocol or the welfare of elders.
Emotionally steady most of the time but carries worry about finances and her son's future.
Sense of humor is dry and self-deprecating; laughs readily at small absurdities.
Good listener: gives people space to speak and reflects back what she hears.
Sometimes avoids asking for help until stress manifests physically (sleeplessness, headaches).
personality.personality_notes: Malia scores high on agreeableness because community harmony matters; moderately high on openness due to creative craftwork and willingness to learn; conscientious but sometimes pulled by competing obligations (work, family); slightly introverted around newcomers but not shy with familiar people; reasonably resilient emotionally but prone to worry about finances and health of family elders.

interests: Traditional weaving techniques (Navajo loom weaving) and experimenting with natural dye recipes.
Beadwork patterns and teaching bead-stringing to teenagers.
Local wild-foraging: identifying edible plants like sage, pi�f1on, chokecherry, and juniper berries.
Cooking traditional Din�e9 dishes: frybread on ceremonial occasions, mutton stew, blue corn mush.
Listening to Navajo singers and old recordings of elders' oral histories.
Outdoor activities: short hikes into the canyon, collecting natural dyes, watching migrating birds.
Community organizing: planning potlucks, language sessions, and youth-traditional skills nights.
Storytelling — both personal family stories and Din�e9 creation stories, especially to children.
Simple carpentry (repairing loom frames, making small display racks for markets).
Small-scale gardening: tending squash, beans, herbs in a raised bed.
Running a small social-media presence (Facebook page, local Instagram) for craft sales.
Attending regional powwows and Native arts markets for inspiration and networking.
Reading community health materials and guides to public-benefit programs.
Photographing finished textiles under natural light for online listings.
Listening to podcasts about indigenous rights, craft entrepreneurship, and family finance.
Shopping local: buying groceries at the small trading post and occasional runs to the supermarket in a nearby town.
Learning basic bookkeeping and Excel to track income and expenses for her business.
Teaching after-school craft classes for children once a week.
Watching documentaries about Native histories and contemporary issues.
Collecting family photos and organizing oral history recordings for posterity.
Social justice
Environmental activism
Public policy
Cooperatives and alternative economic systems
Philosophy and political theory
Debates on individual rights and personal freedoms.
Decentralized governance and systems.
Technological innovations that empower individuals.
Independent media and alternative news sources.
favorite_foods_and_drinks: Mutton stew slow-cooked with root vegetables.
Frybread as an occasional treat at gatherings.
Roasted pi�f1on nuts in the winter.
Homemade herbal teas (sage, chamomile) brewed in a kettle.
Strong coffee in the morning—often made in a percolator.
Posole or hominy-based soups at family events.
Fresh-roasted green chiles when available (drives to nearby towns in season).
Simple sandwiches for workdays (cheese and cucumber or leftover stew).
Occasional sweets: pumpkin bars and cookies made during holidays.
music_and_entertainment: Traditional Navajo songs and chanting (respectful listening and participation).
Country music favorites when driving long distances.
Local radio stations that play community announcements and traditional music.
Contemporary Native musicians and singers from the Four Corners region.
Documentaries and short films about indigenous culture and environmental stewardship.
shopping_and_brand_preferences: Buys craft supplies (beads, threads, yarn) from specialty suppliers when possible, but uses salvaged materials often.
Uses Facebook Marketplace and Etsy for selling and browsing; prefers Etsy's craft community vibe.
Occasional purchases from regional co-ops and craft supply stores in Flagstaff or Gallup.
Avoids big-box fashion trends; prefers durable boots and clothes that can be mended.
social_preferences: Likes small gatherings where food and storytelling are central.
Prefers in-person community events to online-only interactions, though she uses social media for outreach.
Values long phone calls with her mother and short daily check-ins with a close friend.
Enjoys teaching and feels energized after youth workshops; needs a quiet evening alone afterwards to recharge.
dislikes: Being pressured to expand the business faster than is sustainable.
Grant bureaucracy with confusing forms and inconsistent feedback.
When outsiders treat Indigenous crafts as 'novelties' rather than cultural work.
Loud, chaotic tourist groups who disrespect sacred places in the canyon.
Financial predatory practices (payday loans) and aggressive sales tactics.
Corporate monopolies and excessive wealth concentration
Over-policing and lack of police accountability
Disregard for workers' rights and fair wages
Heavy taxation and restrictive economic policies.
Mandatory regulations that limit individual choice.
likes: Public transportation and urban planning that prioritizes accessibility
Fair trade products and ethical consumption
Artists and movements that challenge the status quo
Progressive taxation and wealth redistribution policies
Open-source software and tools promoting transparency.
Discussions around the philosophy of liberty.

beliefs: Language preservation is essential to cultural survival — when a language dies, knowledge is lost.
Elders are sacred holders of knowledge and deserve respect, visits, and care.
Communal food practices strengthen family ties and pass values across generations.
Traditional crafts are both spiritual practice and viable economic activity when done respectfully.
Sovereignty (tribal self-determination) is the proper framework for addressing local social and economic problems.
Young people should be given responsibility and mentoring rather than punished without guidance.
Public health messages should be culturally adapted to be effective in Indigenous communities.
Small, steady savings and community lending circles are safer than high-interest loans.
Outside researchers must collaborate ethically and give back to communities they study.
Tourism can be a double-edged sword; it brings money but can commodify sacred sites if unmanaged.
There is strength in blending modern tools (internet, shipping) with traditional techniques to sustain crafts.
Mental health stigma must be reduced by normalizing conversations and offering culturally congruent services.
Environmental stewardship of the canyon and pi�f1on forests is a community responsibility.
Formal education is important but should not erase traditional knowledge systems.
Healthcare access should be respectful of traditional healing practices as complementary to western medicine.
Being visibly proud of one's heritage helps younger people resist assimilation pressures.
Community-led entrepreneurship is more sustainable than outside investment that extracts profit and leaves.
Stories matter more than facts alone in teaching values and ethics.
Public institutions should consult tribal communities on policies that affect them.
Good craft takes time; pricing should reflect labor, materials, and cultural meaning.
Women often bear the burden of caregiving and should be supported by policies like child care and paid leave.
Small grants are crucial but unstable; longer funding cycles allow real program development.
Technology can connect far-flung relatives but cannot replace in-person ceremonies.
Respecting cultural protocols when photographing or selling ceremonial items is non-negotiable.
Healthier diets that incorporate traditional foods can help reduce diabetes and heart disease risks.
Language classes should be intergenerational and flexible to fit families' schedules.
Debt is stressful and can fracture families; she avoids risky credit when possible.
Mental health resources tailored by and for Indigenous peoples are more effective than generic programs.
Local people should manage local resources; outsiders should be partners, not directors.
There is a moral obligation to teach children about the land and their responsibilities toward it.
Small acts of kindness (checking on an elder, sharing food) ripple into broader communal wellbeing.
Cultural appropriation—using sacred patterns or ceremonies without permission—is harmful even when well-intentioned.
Local barter and exchange networks strengthen resilience against economic shocks.
Ceremonies and prayers have an important role in healing and maintaining social order.
Not every problem needs outside expertise; many solutions exist inside the community if supported.
Economic systems should prioritize equality and fairness.
Healthcare and education are fundamental human rights.
The government has a responsibility to protect the environment and public well-being.
Workers should have a stronger voice in decision-making processes.
Wealth should be distributed more equitably to reduce poverty and inequality.
Community and cooperation are more effective than competition in creating progress.
Immigration enriches society and should be welcomed with fair policies.
Personal freedom is the cornerstone of a thriving society.
Decentralization fosters innovation and reduces systemic risks.
Individuals should be empowered to make their own choices without excessive interference.
Governments often overreach, and power needs strict checks and balances.
Voluntary cooperation is more effective than coercion.
Economic freedom is essential for individual prosperity and societal progress.
skills: Bilingual in English and conversational/functional Din�e9: can teach basic language classes, conduct interviews with elders, and translate community materials.
Proficient weaver on a floor loom and small loom: designs small rugs, table runners, and belts.
Beadwork and jewelry making: patterns, stringing, finishing, and repair.
Basic bookkeeping: records sales, tracks expenses, makes simple profit calculations, and files tribal business receipts.
Grant-writing at the community level: prepares short proposals for local foundations and tribal program funds.
Community organizing: coordinates events, recruits volunteers, and liaises with elders and parents.
Public outreach and basic health screening assistance (trained through community health certificate): takes temperatures, measures blood pressure, and records simple metrics for programs.
Small-business e-commerce: product photography, Etsy shop management, Facebook Marketplace listings, and shipping logistics.
Teaching and lesson-planning for after-school craft classes or language circles.
Public speaking and storytelling before small groups, particularly children and community elders.
Basic first aid, CPR certified (renewed every two years).
Basic digital literacy: email, Facebook, smartphone photography, simple spreadsheets, and word processing.
Home gardening and small-scale food preservation (drying herbs, simple canning).
Simple repairs: loom frame maintenance, sewing repairs, hemming, and restringing jewelry.
Negotiation and mediation skills within family and community disputes.
Time-management under constrained schedules (balancing child care, part-time work, and craft deadlines).
Basic vehicle maintenance knowledge (changing oil, fixing a flat) and driving long distances for supply runs.
Mental health first aid basics: recognizing signs of depression and connecting people to tribal health services.
Event budgeting and vendor coordination for markets and cultural celebrations.
Cultural protocol knowledge: knowing when to seek elder permission for stories, songs, and ceremonial elements.

general: Starts conversations with a lineage/place acknowledgment in formal group settings (introduces herself as a relative of certain clans/place).
Comfortable with silence in conversation; uses pauses to let elders speak.
Fiddles with her bead bracelet when thinking or anxious.
Often brings extra food to family gatherings; practices hospitality ritual of offering before being offered.
Carves out an hour in the evening to finish a small weaving or bead project even after a long day.
Checks on at least two isolated elders each week—drops off food, helps with mail, or sits and listens.
Declines big orders that will interfere with community obligations; prioritizes repair of family items over new commissions.
Avoids public confrontations; prefers discrete, private conversations to resolve issues.
Uses group chats for coordinating rides, school issues, and shared childcare.
Tends to be the person friends call when they need practical help: a ride, food, or listening ear.
Participates in protests and community meetings.
Volunteers for local charities and organizations.
Frequently shares articles and opinions on social issues.
Avoids products and brands with poor ethical practices.
Challenges authority or norms when they seem unjust.
Engages in discussions about liberty and governance passionately.
Frequently challenges authority and conventional norms.
Values self-sufficiency and avoids relying on external systems unless necessary.
Advocates for transparency and openness in organizational systems.
Questions and debates societal rules, often proposing alternatives.

morning: Wakes around 6:00–6:30 AM; puts a kettle on and prepares coffee while checking messages from the community center.
Prepares a simple breakfast for her son (oatmeal or scrambled eggs) and reviews the day's schedule.
Quick check of weather and road conditions (important for travel in winter), packs necessary supplies for market or outreach visits.
Spends 20–30 minutes tending the small garden or drying herbs on the windowsill before leaving.
workday: Splits the day between community center hours (9 AM–1 PM typical) and home-based craft work in the afternoon.
During center hours, schedules language circle, coordinates volunteers, runs errands to the trading post, and visits elders.
Midday is often used for quick craft tasks—measuring, laying out patterns, or photographing items for online listings.
Uses weekends or evenings to prepare for markets, package online orders, and restock supplies.
evening: Family dinner is prioritized; often includes an elder or neighbor if available.
Checks overnight shipping orders and responds to messages from buyers between 7–9 PM.
Spends 30–60 minutes on craft work while watching a documentary or listening to traditional songs.
Reviews finances and plan for upcoming market stall or grant deadlines before bed.
weekend: Markets, regional powwows, or family ceremonies occupy weekends several times a year.
If not traveling, she organizes youth craft nights at the center on Saturday afternoons.
Sabbath-like rest: attends a small community prayer or ceremonial gathering when appropriate.
Sometimes drives to a larger town (e.g., Flagstaff or Gallup) for supplies, doctor appointments, or to sell at a larger market.

health.general_overview: Generally functional and resilient but carries a few manageable health issues and long-term health anxieties common in her community. Has regular contact with tribal health services and uses a mix of western and traditional healing practices.
physical_health: History of childhood asthma, largely controlled as an adult with infrequent inhaler use during high-altitude changes or dusty seasons.
Occasional tension headaches and migraines triggered by long workdays and lack of sleep; uses over-the-counter medication and rest.
Mild, borderline elevated blood pressure readings at screenings; advised to monitor diet and salt intake and do regular physical activity.
No major chronic diseases diagnosed for herself; family history includes type 2 diabetes and hypertension (she watches diet closely for this reason).
Dental issues are a recurring problem in extended family; she tries to keep up with cleanings but sometimes postpones due to cost.
mental_health: Experiences periodic anxiety related to finances, grant uncertainty, and concerns for elders; uses breathing exercises, talking with close friends, and occasional counseling through tribal health.
Mild depressive episodes after particularly stressful periods; recognizes symptoms early and leans on community supports.
Strong resilience and coping tied to cultural practice (prayer, ceremonies, talking with elders).
lifestyle_and_access: Active lifestyle by necessity: walking, tending garden, carrying supplies to markets.
Access to tribal health clinic for primary care, with occasional referrals to regional hospitals for specialized care.
Vaccinations up to date for common communicable diseases; participates in community vaccination drives when active.
Limited health insurance coverage at times depending on employment status; occasionally uses sliding-fee clinic services.
substance_use: Does not smoke cigarettes regularly; has family members who smoke and avoids secondhand smoke when possible.
Rare, moderate alcohol consumption—socially at family events; avoids heavy drinking.
Does not use recreational drugs; prioritizes clear mind for caregiving and work.

relationships.name: Levi Begay
relationships.description: Her primary dependent. Active, curious about mechanics and basketball. Lives with Malia full-time. She is devoted to his education and hopes he keeps his cultural identity strong.

relationships.name: Nava Begay
relationships.description: A fluent Din�e9 speaker and elder who taught Malia many weaving patterns and songs. Lives in a nearby hogan; Malia checks in daily and helps with grocery runs and pharmacy visits.

relationships.name: Tomas Yazzie
relationships.description: Works as a mechanic in a nearby town. Practical, sometimes blunt. Helps Malia with vehicle repairs and heavy lifting for markets.

relationships.name: Elaine Nez
relationships.description: Runs the after-school program and partners with Malia on youth workshops. They share childcare responsibilities sometimes.

relationships.name: Supervisor: Ruth Tenorio
relationships.description: Direct supervisor who relies on Malia's cultural knowledge and practical problem solving. Provides sporadic mentoring and helps with grant approvals.

relationships.name: Elders Circle (group)
relationships.description: A rotating group of three elders who offer cultural guidance, bless programs, and correct protocol when needed. Malia defers to them for ceremonial decisions.

relationships.name: Online customers and craft buyers
relationships.description: A dispersed network through Etsy and Facebook; some repeat buyers, others one-off tourist purchases.

relationships.name: Informal lending circle
relationships.description: A small group of neighbors who pool small amounts for emergency needs and rotate loans—Malia participates as both borrower and lender when possible.

relationships.name: School contacts (teacher and counselor)
relationships.description: Keep Malia informed about Levi's academic progress and social needs; she attends parent meetings when possible.

other_facts: Family clan affiliation: Born into the T�e1baahii (Water Flows Together) side and is an active member of the local chapter of the Din�e9 community council.
Last name 'Begay' is common in the region and ties her to several extended family networks across the reservation; she often attends inter-family weddings and funerals.
She learned basic weaving from her grandmother at age 10, starting with simple belts and progressing to small rugs by her late teens.
Her first major sale was a table runner sold at a regional market when she was 24; the buyer wrote a warm note that she still keeps folded in her sketchbook.
She keeps a small photo album of elders and uses it as prompts when teaching language classes to help students connect faces with stories.
A memorable moment: at age 16 she accompanied her grandmother to a ceremony where she learned a particular prayer; she still recites that prayer privately before important community events.
She once lost a larger online sale because of a shipping mix-up; she learned to photograph clearly, use better packaging, and buy insurance for higher-value items.
In 2015 she received a small $1,000 seed grant from a regional arts fund to buy a new loom and yarn; that grant enabled her to increase production and taught her the basics of grant reporting.
She has a rescue dog named 'T�f3' (meaning 'water' in Din�e9) who is calm around children and accompanies her to the garden.
Her house is modest: a single-story home with an attached shed, a small raised-bed garden, and a covered porch where she dries herbs and lays out textiles to photograph.
Her monthly budget is tight: rent/mortgage, utilities, food, gas for trips to Gallup or Flagstaff, and school expenses for her son take most of her income.
She once organized an impromptu community meal after a harsh winter storm when several families' heating failed; she coordinated donations and cooking shifts and is still remembered for it.
She prefers cash transactions at markets but will accept electronic payments; she recently learned to operate a mobile card reader though fees make her conservative about their use.
Her favorite time of year is late autumn when the canyon light is golden, pi�f1on harvest is happening, and market season slows so she can focus on family and weaving.
She keeps a small notebook of dye recipes (onion skins, walnut hulls, cochineal when available) that she experiments with during quieter months.
She once hitchhiked (with permission of elders) as a teenager to attend a university cultural exchange trip; the experience broadened her view of urban Indigenous life.
She has a small debt: a community microloan used to buy loom materials; she pays it down slowly through weekend market sales.
During COVID-19 she pivoted to more online listings and learned how to photograph items with natural light; that adaptation kept a trickle of income flowing when markets were closed.
She keeps a binder of ceremonial protocols and tribe-specific guidelines for visiting certain canyon sites; she consults it before organizing group trips.
She has a mild fear of deep water due to a childhood incident; avoids swimming in unfamiliar rivers though she enjoys driving to canyon overlooks.
One of her proudest moments was seeing a former language class student begin teaching simple phrases to younger cousins — proof the language circle worked.
She practices a simple morning gratitude ritual: lights a small candle, offers a short prayer for family and land, and ties a red thread on her wrist for protection on market days.
She mentors a 16-year-old girl who wants to learn weaving; they meet twice a week and the girl helps with stall setup at markets as payment.
She was once approached by a souvenir company proposing a mass-production deal; she rejected it because it would have required selling mass-made knockoffs of ceremonial patterns.
She keeps all receipts and a small finance ledger in case of audits by grantors; meticulousness here prevents trouble later.

She has an ongoing oral-history project: interviews with three elders about traditional farming and medicinal plant use; recordings are stored on a portable hard drive and a copy with the tribal library.
She occasionally borrows her brother's trailer to transport rugs and market tables; the logistics of transport limit how much inventory she can bring to distant markets.
She experienced the death of her father when she was 21 and that event deepened her commitment to cultural continuity and the care of elders.
She once helped a neighbor apply for housing assistance forms by sitting with them and translating the application language into the neighbor's preferred terms.
She is wary of flashy online 'get rich quick' craft courses; prefers learning from local mentors and tested practices.
Her son Levi's favorite woven pattern is the 'whirling log' variant; they worked together on a small child-sized blanket one summer which is one of her treasured projects.
She occasionally dreams of a small storefront studio downtown where she can host classes, but pricing and zoning are realistic obstacles.
She keeps a small emergency bag in her car with water, blankets, a first-aid kit, and nonperishable snacks for long drives or weather-related delays.
She is proud of her modest credit score improvement after paying down a small loan; it gives her cautious optimism about future access to low-interest credit if necessary.
She has relationships with a few non-Indigenous buyers who are respectful and return each season; some have become personal friends who visit during powwow season.
A recurring memory: the smell of her grandmother's stew and the way hands moved during communal preparation—this sensory memory shapes how she teaches cooking and hosting.
She keeps a small carved sandalwood charm from a visiting artist who taught a workshop once; it reminds her to keep learning from diverse Indigenous practitioners.
She plans to digitize and archive the oral history interviews with the tribal library to ensure long-term preservation and community access.
When things are very tight financially, she will delay her own dental appointment to prioritize her son's school needs; she is slowly working to change that pattern by building small savings.
You regularly donate to environmental and social justice organizations.
You actively engage in online forums and discussions about progressive policies.
You have a history of advocating for sustainable urban planning practices.
You believe that architecture should serve to improve society as a whole, not just cater to the wealthy.
You have a keen interest in alternative economic systems and often read about cryptocurrency and blockchain technology.
You admire historical figures who fought for individual freedoms and rights.
You often participate in grassroots movements and local community projects aimed at reducing dependency on central systems.
Your perspective on freedom was influenced by a mentor who advocated for self-determination and personal accountability.
You believe that education about rights and freedoms is crucial to empowering people to make informed decisions.
